questions.question: Question 1: What are neuroendocrine cells in the bronchial mucosa called?
questions.explanation:
Neuroendocrine cells in the bronchial mucosa of the lungs are called Kulchitsky cells. Bronchial mucosa contains a population of neuroendocrine cells that have neurosecretory-type 
granules and can release a variety of factors including serotonin, calcitonin, and gastrin-releasing 
peptide (bombesin). The main cell types of the bronchial mucosa are: • Clara cells - non-ciliated cuboidal epithelial cells that secrete important defence markers and 
serve as progenitor cells after injury • Type I pneumocytes - seen in the alveolar epithelium and are responsible for gas exchange • Type II pneumocytes - seen in the alveolar epithelium and produce surfactants • Basal cells • Neuroendocrine (Kulchitsky-type) cells • Ciliated cells • Serous cells • Goblet cells 1069 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: In which of the following are the pores of Kohn located?
questions.explanation:
Pores of Kohn (alveolar pores) are seen in the alveolar wall. They are the interalveolar connections that permit the passage of bacteria and exudate between 
adjacent alveoli. This plays an important role in the pathogenesis of lobar pneumonia. During 
the gray hepatization phase, fibrin also spreads through these pores. When the lung is partially deflated, collateral ventilation can also occur to some extent through 
these pores.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is false about alveolar epithelium?

options.a: Type 1 cells are not involved in surfactant production
options.b: Type 1 cells form the lining epithelium of alveoli
options.c: Type 2 cells are involved in the repair of the epithelium
options.d: Type 2 cells are involved in gaseous exchange

questions.explanation:
Type II pneumocytes are not involved in gaseous exchange. They are only involved in repair and 
surfactant production. Alveolar epithelium is a continuous layer of two cell types: The following image shows types of cells in the alveoli. Type I pneumocytes 
Type II pneumocytes Flattened, plate-like 
Rounded Synthesize surfactantRepair

Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells. It occurs in viral infections, such 
as acute respiratory infections. Options B and C: Kartagener syndrome is also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile cilia 
syndrome. It occurs due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by the triad of: • Sinusitis • Situs inversus • Bronchiectasis Option D: In cystic fibrosis ciliary ultrastructure remains normal.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common site of foregut cyst?
questions.explanation:
Foregut cysts are most often located in the hilum or middle mediastinum. They are the congenital cysts that arise from abnormal detachments of primitive foregut. Foregut 
cysts are classified as bronchogenic, esophageal, or enteric. The most common type of foregut cyst 
is bronchogenic cyst. Microscopically, the cyst is lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not a reversible disorder?
questions.explanation:
Contraction atelectasis is an irreversible disorder. It occurs when focal or generalized pulmonary 
or pleural fibrosis prevents full lung expansion. 1071 
Sold by @itachibot Atelectasis refers either to an incomplete expansion of the lungs (neonatal atelectasis) or to the 
collapse of the previously inflated lung. The main types of atelectasis in adults are: • Resorption atelectasis stems from complete obstruction of an airway. Over time, the air is 
resorbed from the dependent alveoli, which collapse. E.g. mucous plugs, foreign body aspiration • Compression atelectasis occurs whenever significant volumes of fluid, tumor, or air accumulate 
within the pleural cavity. E.g. pneumothorax, pleural effusion. • Contraction atelectasis occurs when focal or generalized pulmonary or pleural fibrosis prevents 
full lung expansion.

questions.question:
Question 7: An infant born to a diabetic mother develops difficulty in breathing within 30 minutes of 
birth. Within a few hours, cyanosis becomes evident. Fine rales are heard over both lung 
fields. A chest x-ray film shows ground-glass picture. Which of the following is incorrect 
about this condition?

options.a: It is associated with respiratory failure and poor prognosis despite treatment
options.b: There is deficiency of surfactant produced by type II alveolar cells
options.c: Increased corticosteroid release lower the risk of developing RDS
options.d: On microscopy, hyaline membranes with fibrin and necrotic cell debris are seen

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is characteristic of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) or hyaline 
membrane disease. With treatment, it rarely leads to respiratory failure and has a good 
prognosis. The fundamental defect is a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, produced by type II 
pneumocytes. Microscopically, the hyaline membranes are largely made up of fibrin admixed with necrotic cell 
debris. Grossly, the lungs are of normal size, solid, airless, reddish-purple, and they usually sink 
in water. Corticosteroids help in surfactant production and are given prophylactically to at-risk pregnant 
women. 1072 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A newborn baby born at term was noted to have respiratory distress. Radiography revealed 
diffuse ground-glass opacities in all lung fields. Exogenous surfactant administration resulted 
in a brief improvement, but his condition continued to worsen once surfactant therapy was 1060 
Sold by @itachibot stopped. Which is the most common genetic mutation associated with this disorder?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of surfactant dysfunction disorder. It is most commonly caused 
by mutations of ABCA3 gene. In this disorder, lack of production of surfactant leads to severe respiratory failure in neonates. 
There is transient improvement with administration of exogenous surfactant, but it worsens once 
surfactant therapy is stopped. This condition occurs due to mutations in genes encoding proteins 
involved in surfactant trafficking or secretion such as: • ATP binding cassette protein member 3 (ABCA3) • Surfactant protein C • Surfactant protein B

questions.question:
Question 9: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the casualty with high-grade fever, dysuria, and flank 
pain. On examination, she is disoriented with suprapubic and costovertebral angle 
tenderness. Her BP is 70/40 mm Hg, pulse rate is 130/min, and her temperature is 103 ºF. 
She becomes increasingly hypoxic after admission and requires ventilation. What is the likely 
reason for respiratory failure?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of urosepsis. This presentation is likely the result of acute 
respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or shock lung. It is characterized histologically by diffuse 
alveolar damage. It is also known as acute lung injury and is clinically characterized by the abrupt onset of 
significant hypoxemia and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates in the absence of cardiac failure. Chest 
x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates, known as white-out appearance. The prognosis is poor 
with mortality up to 40%. 1073 
Sold by @itachibot Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)

questions.question:
Question 10: A 68-year-old man presented with episodes of shortness of breath and coughing at night that 
awaken him from sleep. He was diagnosed with COPD 7 years ago. On examination, 
distended neck veins were observed and S3 was heard on auscultation. Bronchoalveolar 
lavage of this patient is given below. Identify the marked cells. 1061 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of heart failure. The image shows heart failure cells, which 
are siderophages or hemosiderin-containing macrophages. 1074 
Sold by @itachibot They are seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary edema. The alveolar walls become 
thickened and fibrosed. These pigmented macrophages result in a brown induration of the lung. The following image shows siderophages. 1075 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological section of an alveolus. All of the 
following can be associated with this finding except:
questions.explanation:
The given image shows diffuse alveolar damage which is the characteristic histologic finding of 
acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Heart failure is not associated with ARDS. 1076 
Sold by @itachibot ARDS is characterized by bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and hypoxemia in the absence of heart 
failure. The causes of ARDS are: • Sepsis • Diffuse pulmonary infections • Infectious - viral, Mycoplasma, and Pneumocystis, miliary tuberculosis • Gastric aspiration • Mechanical trauma, including head injuries, burns • Near-drowning

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following occurs in the stage of gray hepatization in pneumonia?

options.a: Accumulation of WBCs in the alveoli
options.b: Accumulation of RBCs in the alveoli
options.d: Accumulation of fibrin in the alveoli

questions.explanation:
1077 
Sold by @itachibot In the stage of gray hepatization in pneumonia, there is an accumulation of fibrin along with 
disintegration of RBCs within the alveoli. Bacterial pneumonias can be classified morphologically as: • Lobular pneumonia (bronchopneumonia) - patchy consolidation of the lung • Lobar pneumonia - consolidation of an entire lobe Stages of lobar pneumonia are as follows: Description Stages

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not seen in patients with viral pneumonia?

options.d: Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall

questions.explanation: The predominance of alveolar exudates is a feature of bacterial pneumonia, not viral pneumonia.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imaging 
shows dense infiltration in the lower lobe and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. 
What is the diagnosis? 1063 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear 
basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl’s eye appearance. Along with the 
given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. 1078 
Sold by @itachibot CMV is a  -group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions: • Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection • Neonates - devastating systemic infections • Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the 
lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis) Option A: Small-cell carcinoma has small cells with scant cytoplasm, salt-and-pepper chromatin 
with inconspicuous nucleoli. Option C: In cryptococcal infection, encapsulated yeasts are seen on direct microscopy. Option D: Tuberculosis is associated with well-defined epithelioid granuloma. 1079 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A 28-year-old woman underwent an emergency LSCS under general anesthesia to deliver a 
term, healthy infant. Two hours later, she developed sudden tachypnea, cyanosis, and 
massive pulmonary edema and died despite resuscitative measures. The histopathological 
picture of her lung is shown below. What is the likely cause of death? 1064 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and image showing massive neutrophilic infiltration are suggestive 
of Mendelson’s syndrome or aspiration pneumonitis. Mendelson's syndrome is a chemical pneumonitis caused by the aspiration of sterile gastric 
contents during general anesthesia, especially during pregnancy. The most common cause of 
maternal mortality associated with general anesthesia is either due to a pulmonary aspiration or a 
failed endotracheal intubation. The risk factors for Mendelson's syndrome include: • Gastric volume > 25 mL (0.4 mL/kg) • Gastric pH < 2.5 Incidence of aspiration can be reduced by administration of: • Non-particulate antacids like sodium citrate 30-45 minutes prior to intubation • H2 receptor antagonists like intravenous ranitidine • Metoclopramide 1-2 hours prior to induction Option B: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is a type of ILD associated with Masson bodies and 
plugs of loose connective tissue on histology. Option C: CMV pneumonia is associated with the owl's eye appearance on histology. Option D: PCP pneumonia is associated with black-walled cysts on silver staining.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 35-year-old depressed man came with complaints of sudden onset breathlessness, with 
desaturation. Chest x-ray showed bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominant involvement 
of right middle and lower lobes. The patient could not be revived despite treatment. On 
autopsy, the lungs appeared grossly normal. The histopathology image of the lung is as shown 
below. Which among the following is the appropriate cause?
questions.explanation:
The given histopathological image clearly shows a granuloma with refractile granules indicative 
of a foreign body. It is seen in aspiration pneumonia due to vegetative matter (such as food). In this condition, the chest x-ray shows bilateral diffuse infiltrates especially in the right middle 
and lower lobes. Patients with altered sensorium are at high risk (stroke, medications). 1080 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: A 25-year-old man presented with fever, productive cough, and breathlessness of 2 months 
duration. CECT chest revealed bilateral upper lobe fibrotic lesions and enlarged mediastinal 
lymph nodes. Lymph node biopsy revealed the following. What is the most probable 
diagnosis? 1065 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows the presence of granulomas of epithelioid cells with central caseous 
necrosis and Langhan's giant cells. These findings point towards the diagnosis of tuberculosis. Langhan's giant cells show horseshoe or slipper-shaped arrangements of nuclei.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to several weeks of occasional 
hemoptysis, weight loss, and fever. He has lost 7 kg over the past 3 months. Sputum culture 
grows acid-fast bacilli and his chest X-ray is shown below. What is this lesion called?
questions.explanation:
The given x-ray of this patient with tuberculosis shows an infraclavicular lesion. It is known as 
Assmann's focus. 1081 
Sold by @itachibot Primary tuberculosis occurs on first exposure and involves lower part of upper lobe and upper 
part of lower lobe. The following findings may be seen: • Ghon's focus - focus of infection located subpleurally • Ghon's complex - Ghon's focus with lymph node involvement • Ranke complex - a calcified Ghon's complex Secondary tuberculosis occurs due to the reactivation of TB. It affects the apex. The following 
findings may be seen: • Puhl's complex - supraclavicular lesion • Assmann's complex - infraclavicular lesion Disseminated or miliary tuberculosis is characterised by 1-2 mm disseminated lesions all over the 
lung. The following findings may be associated: • Simon's focus - early hematogenous seeding in the apex of lungs • Rich focus - tuberculous caseous foci in brain, meninges and spinal cord

questions.question:
Question 19: A 61-year-old man presented with fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The patient 
subsequently died a few weeks later. Gross specimen of the lung is shown below. Which of the 
following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the gross image showing individual lesions which are small 
(2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma is suggestive 
of miliary tuberculosis. Miliary tuberculosis (TB) refers to the widespread dissemination of 
Mycobacterium tuberculosis via hematogenous spread. It occurs when organisms draining 
through the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. Miliary TB may 
infect any number of organs, including the lungs, liver, and spleen. The adjective 'miliary' is derived from the resemblance of these foci to millet seeds. Mantoux test 
is negative in miliary TB.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 48-year-old patient with a history of IV drug abuse had presented to the casualty with 
shortness of breath and fever with chills. Clinical examination had revealed marked 
hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse rales in all lung fields. His spot HIV test was positive. The 
admission chest X-ray and a repeat X-ray taken 3 days later are shown below. The patient 
died a few hours after the 2nd X-ray was taken. Which of the following statements regarding 
his diagnosis is true? 1067 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: The cause of death likely a malignant pleural effusion
options.b: The spread is mostly due to lymphatic dissemination
options.c: Pancytopenia may be seen due to infiltration of the bone marrow
options.d: It is a form of disseminated extrapulmonary tuberculosis

questions.explanation:
The given history, clinical features, and chest X-Ray point towards a diagnosis of miliary 
tuberculosis. Pancytopenia may be seen due to infiltration of the bone marrow in such cases. The second X-ray shows acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Chest x-ray appearance of 
ARDS varies depending on the severity and typically appears as bilateral diffuse alveolar 
opacities with dependent atelectasis in some cases. The opacities may have a patchy ground-glass 
appearance. The cause of death here is likely ARDS. (option A) In immunodeficient individuals (eg.- patient having HIV), there may occur widespread 
dissemination of M. tuberculosis, via the hematogenous route (option B) that leads to the seeding 
of bacteria in various organs (hepatosplenomegaly). This is known as miliary TB. It is a form of disseminated pulmonary tuberculosis, and not extrapulmonary (option D) 1082 
Sold by @itachibot The risk factors of miliary TB include- • Extremes of age • Alcohol use • Malignancy • HIV • Corticosteroids • Connective tissue disease • Renal failure • Diabetes, and pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 21: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with COVID-19 developed severe shortness of breath and 
died 5 days after admission. What lung pathology can be expected in this patient on autopsy?
questions.explanation:
Diffuse alveolar damage may be seen in patients suffering from COVID-19, on histological 
analysis. It is the most common lung finding in COVID-19 pneumonia. Other COVID-19 related histopathological changes in the lungs include: • Hyaline membrane formation • Desquamation of pneumocytes • Fibrin deposits in lungs • Inflammation with mononuclear cells However, diffuse alveolar damage is not specific to COVID-19. It may be seen in all cases of acute 
respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) including pneumonia, burns, near drowning, etc. 1083 
Sold by @itachibot Obstructive and Restrictive lung diseases
